description: Initial term of a series of exactly n consecutive Harshad or Niven numbers (a Harshad number is such that is divided by the sum of its digits).
references: J.-M. De Koninck, Ces nombres qui nous fascinent, Entry 110, p. 39, Ellipses, Paris 2008.
links: C. N. Cooper and R. E. Kennedy (1993). On consecutive Niven numbers. Fibonacci Quart, 21, 146-151.
H. G. Grundman (1994). Sequences of consecutive n-Niven numbers. Fibonacci Quarterly 32 (2): 174-175.
B. Wilson (1997). Construction of 2n Consecutive n-Niven Numbers. Fibonacci Quarterly, 35, 122-128.
C. Rivera, Puzzle 129. Earliest sets of K consecutive Harshad Numbers
example: a(3)=110 since 110 is divisible by 2, 111 is divisible by 3, 112 is divisible by 4 but 113 is not divisible by 5.
author: _Carlos Rivera_, Mar 12 2001
extensions: a(8) is found by _Jud McCranie_, Nov 13 2001
a(11)-a(13) are found by _Giovanni Resta_, Feb 21 2008
